marklogic.body:
Hospitals have been offering huge buyouts for practices. Plus, our overhead is getting silly. Seriously, the hospital can outfit a clinic with something like GE Centricity EMR that they maintain, the hospital absorbs the billing and coding, and possibly they even take care of scheduling. It looks good on paper - get rid of the overhead Headache, however, most of the docs I know that have sold out their practices end up quitting within a year once the hospital takes control.
Liability is also an increasing problem - as you mentioned, defensive medicine is a very real one (I do a lot of tests that I don't feel necessary just to appease the patient). Having the hospital deal with the liability issues is a bonus.
Another issue is referral base - specialists Depend on primaries to refer patients. As more and more primaries are absorbed into hospital systems, they tend to refer internally - if you're not part of the system, you're locked out. As a general rule, hospitals loose money on general practitioners, and make it back on the specialists.
If ObamaCare stands, I think ACOs will be a serious issue, and will force almost all docs away from truly private practices.
